## What is it?

[Globalization]{.hp}

> The growing interdependence of the world's economies, cultures, and populations, brought about by cross-border trade in goods and services, technology, and flows of investment, people, and information

<br>

::: {.fragment}
The term is used broadly. 
We focus on international trade and some of the investment flows among advanced economies, mostly focusing on the United States.
:::

---

## Big Picture

There are wide-ranging effects of globalization, but all lessons thus far culminate to these points:

::: {.incremental}
- Complex and politically charged
- As with major technological advances, globalization benefits society as a whole, while harming certain groups
:::

::: {.fragment}
Understanding the relative costs and benefits can pave the way to alleviating problems [while sustaining the wider payoffs]{.hp}
:::

---

## History Lesson

[Globalization]{.hp} took off in the 19th century

<br>

::: {.fragment}
Following centuries of European colonization and trade activity, [first wave of globalization]{.hp} moved forward by steamships, railroads, the telegraph, and refrigeration

<br>

It came alongside [increased economic cooperation]{.hi}. 
This initial trend [eventually waned]{.hi} and crashed in the horrors of [World War I]{.hp}
:::

<br>    

::: {.fragment}
This was followed by post-war [protectionism]{.hp}, the [Great Depression]{.hp}, and [World War II]{.hp}
:::

---

## History Lesson

After WWII, the United States led efforts to [revive internatinoal trade and investment]{.hp} under negotiated ground rules

::: {.fragment .small}
> Bretton Woods Conference (1944): Series of agreements led to [exchange rate system]{.hp} (lasted until 1971); 
> 
> International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), now known as the [World Bank]{.hp} 
> 
> The [International Monetary Fund (IMF)]{.hp}
> 
> Two years later, 23 nations including the UK and US began reducing trade barriers, leading to the [General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT)]{.hp}, which began in 1948. 
:::

::: {.fragment}
We are now in the [Second Wave of Globalization]{.hp}, though it is been marked by periodic downturns and mounting political scrutiny
:::
